Mr.. RANDOLPH has sustained the views we yester-
day threw out as to his incompetency to act as
Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means.
by sending to the Speaker his resignation of the Of
flee. If this step was not the result of reflection


if the objections we urged against his appointment
did not urge him to the measure we are left to
make the only inference which is left at our option
that he was originally appointed by the Speaker,
with the understanding that he should resign so as
to leave the chair vacant for Mir. McDuFFIE. We
can scarcely believe that the Speaker calculated on
a cordial co operation in the Committee between Mr.


RANDOLPH and Mr.. McDUFFIE, since he must have
recolected the contemptuous manner in which the
former expressed himself of the latter, and the in
dignant retort of Mr. McDufFe, some few years
since, in the course of a debate in the House OF
Representatives. 1t is probable that Mr. Randolph
has neither forgotten nor forgiven that retort. 1t
he has not, he could not serve on the Committee
with Mr.. McDuffie ; and if the Speaker knew this.
he must have made the appointment with full
knowledge that 1t would be resigned whether the
step now taken by Mr. Randolph is in fulflment Of
an original understanding or is the effect Of some
sudden insight into his own incompetency, we will


not decide In either case, the effect is the same
MIR. McDufie is the chairman ofthe Committee.
From the National Journal, Dec. Is.

Robeson, Captain Saui, and Captain Richardson,
all q! whom are well recommended as 70 good char
acter and fitness for that Office"


There is certainly an awful squirting in this to-
wards military government, should it ever be the
misfortune of this country to have General Jackson
elected President. s.Shoud the Colonel not sue
ceed," says the General, i" am requested by sew
eral gentlemen from New Orleans to name to you
Captain Robeson, Captai,a Saul, and Captain Rich
ar'son." We doubt not that these Captains were
very clever and deserving gentlemen, but then it sa-
yours too much of the military spirit for our taste
We must confess do not like to see civil offices
filled by mere soldiers. ID.

In the State of NORTH CAROLINA, public mee-
tings continue to be held, successfully, in different
Counties,ior adopting measures to form an elector
al ticket in that State friendly to the reelection of
Mr.. ADAMS to the Presidency. We have received
the proceedings of the meeting held in Beaufort
County, which County, are Informed. is, as well
as many others, decidedly in favor of the Admin
istration-a feeling which is daily gaining ground.
But do not, as at present advised, mean to claim
the vote of that State for Mr.. ADAMS. The Ad-
minstraton, if in minority now, however. is in a
very respectable one, which it is possible may swell
into majority before the day of trial comes.
From, the National MteHgencer.

fhe following paragraph, from the Raleigh Re-
Iglster of Dec. 4, expresses sentiments which ought
to animate the bosom Of every man. The tear OF
being found in majority" is the basest and most
Of all motives and excuses for treache-
Try to ones own convictions.


"a public invitation to the friends of the Admin
lstration. in Wake county, appears in this paper
We trust they will avail themselves of it, and, in
consideration Of the importance of the object which
lis sought to be Effected, will suffer trivial cause
to prevent their attendance at the proposed meeting
We have every encouragement to perseverance.
The efforts which making in every section of the
State by the friends of Civil Government, not only
c,ince that their strength is greater than the most
sangune could have calculated on, but they also
show, that we have on our side many of the first
men in the State, whether considered in reference
to their talents or influence. Let not the friends Of
MIR Adams be deferred from doing their duty, from
the fear Of being found in minority, but let them
reflect that it is far more preferable,

ion have no doubt, in common with myself. read
with feelings of indignation the vile and slanderous
attack upon Kensey Johns, Junr. Esq. in the Della
ware Gazette. That such an attack was unexpect-
GU cannot assert-but that it was wholly unmerit-
ed and uncallel for, none but the miserable and pur-
chased wretch who made it will deny If ever
there was an individual whose amable and unas
snming good qualities could have disarmed political
fancour, that person was Mr.. Johns--but it seems
as II party strife spare nothing. Virtue, char
acler, religion itself is not exempt from its assaults,
For the Del0aUare Journal.

and in the reclessnass Of lis pursuit even the COM
mon decencies and charities OF life are overlooked.
! Mr.. Johns has been wantonly and vulgarly as
salled because, iUIsooth, the present Speaker III
the House of Representatives, has not thought
proper 10 place him any of the standing commit
tees And to Justify what Harker considers in
territorial slight to the State he endeavours to shew,
or rather the pful blockhead asserts. that Mr..
Johns is without sufficient talent and requirements
for such situation This, affirm, is positively
false, and will be iumphantly proved whenever
his abilities put to the test. Mr.. Johns is not a
sudden made man. thrown out by the late political
excitement, which seems to have unhinged every
thing in the State. He has been for eight or ten
years at the Bar of this county, and earned by his
assiduous attention to his profession and amlabe de-
pertinent, not merely the goodwill, but the res
pect OF nearly all his associates Ills friends and
those who brought him forward on IA late Occa-
sion, saw in him degree of intelligence, united
with Il manly rectitude of purpose, which they
thought fully qualified him for his present situa-
ton. They knew that his judgment was sound.
and that his mind was sufficiently stored with
the important principles of law and legislation, to
render him safe depository of the trust they conf
ded to him. And they know and feel that the
cause of the omission alluded to- grows out of ve-
ry different from the assigned in the Ga
zette. They cannot permit themselves to doubt,
nor will any dsinterested and candid man (atter ex
aminng the complexion of the Committees that
have been appointed) that the why Mr..
Johns was passed over by the Speaker, was simply
because he known to be friendly to the present
Administration. What this state of things augurs
for the prosperity othe Country, is topic we will
not discuss.


Fortunately, the polluted source from which this
attack emenates, deplives it of the power to do mis-
chief-and nothing but the possibility of its receiv
ing credence abroad, where his character is unknown,
has induced me to notice it. should add, that the
writer of the present remarks, is not personal
friend of Mr.. Johns and that he has been inAuenc-
ed in what he has said solely from desire to do
justice. confess too, that am unwilling, as a
Deawarlan, to stand silently and see the reputation
Of man whom majority of my State has thought
worthy to represent her in Congress, assailed and
talsitied by any ignorant and degraded puppy who
may chance to edit paper And, additionally,
object that such creature as Harker, the willing
and humble tool of all or any who will consent to
employ him. should without contradiction, assume
to himself the province OF a public sentinel" We
Sir, who reside in this part of the country, knoU
him to be neither sentinel nor the organ of an,
party in the State. The most respectable of the


old Federalists, of whom he has been the worst en-


emy, and whose party he has so long labored t.


destroy, gave him up, one after another, some TIM
age. ne oe'noCFauC party always heio nun y


contempt. The present genuine &C bona .fde" Jack


sonitcs are afraid of his principles; for they Can


not forget that he has denounced their CHIEF " a


the most Objectionable of all the candidates for tn


presidency" And the eleventh hour Jackson mer
. who have the honor, or the disgrace to enrol hil
in their ranks not in very good circulation then
sclves, and at all events cannot be dgned with th
:: name ofa party. Let him. however, belong to wha


ever political sect he may, he has lost what litt
standing he had in the estimation of the better pa
0 of society, who in him the robber of priva
t reputation, and the ready sponsor of every politics
s. heresy. VlNDEA'

Mr.. Diclerson, Senator of the United States
from New Jersey, has declared MS intention of re-
signing his seat at the close of the present session.
The people whom that Honorable gentleman con-
tinues to msrepresent will doubtless be much pleas
ed when they learn his determination.

New ORLEANS, Nov. 22,-More Duels-A duel
took place on Sunday morning last, between Mr.
Dangerfield and Mi. Buckner, of Natchez. On
the third fire, the former mortally wounded, and
expired in three hours after.


DR. Newell and General Coffee fought duel at
jackson, Mississippi, few days since; the former
was wounded, but not mOrtally.

Governor Trmblc's message sustans the power
of Congress to protect domestic industry, in very
lucid and powerful manner, and urges the exped-
ency of it but it seems unnecessary to lay his
views before our readers, at this time, since simi-
lar statements have been SO lately presenedto them
Of the Administration of the General Government,
he thus speaks.
Nor have we less cause to feel grateful when con-
templatiny the favorable and prosperous condition
of our common country. Under the guidance OF an
enlightened and liberal Administration, the great in
teress of the nation have continued to prosper, her
resources have been increased, the public debt re-
duced, and by mild, but firm execution Of the laws,
the rights ofhe citizens have been protected peace
and tranquility maintained, (both in our foreign u
domestic relations,) without resort to force and
under the peaceful influence OF our free institutions
we may repose in the perfect enjoyments OF civil
and religious liberty freedom ofthought ofspeech
and there are ''none to hurt or make US AFRAID

Of the Committee of Ways and Means-urging his
inability to discharge the duties in consequence of the
avery feeble state of his heath''-His voice is said

clamaton memory, and late an expounder OF the
apocaypse, was added to the Committee after the
House excused Mr.. Randolph. Mr.. M'Dutiie be-
comes the Chairman.


The Miners Journal-published in Schuylkill
county, Penn. states that Gov. Shulze cannot be
spared from that State for the Vice Presidency
and observes If his name vice President,
were connected with that of Mr. Adams, on the
Presidential ticket there is no doubt that ticket
would succeed in Pennsylvania by large nayority
The cause of the administration, however, requires
no such extraneous aid. Judging from the present
aspect of things, we are firmly Of the opinion, that
MIR. Adams will ultimately receive thevote Of Penn
sylvania."


We publish, to day, that part of the Treasury Re-
port which relates to the protection of Home Indus
try, to which we invite the particular attention o
the reader The first part oft treats Of the state
the Finances, and the liquidation Of the public debt
which, in substance has been laid before the reader
The Secretary, in conclusion, is not inattentive t.
the claims of Foreign Commerce, and points ou
some expedents for augmenting it, and gives the es
Inmates for the following ycar-caculating that tn
ordinary expenses will be paid-and ten millions 9
public debt, and leaving between two and three mil


lions in the Treasury at the end of thr year.

We were very forcibly struck with the following
paragraph, in General Jackson's letter to the Post
Master General in favor of Col. Croghan:


'.Should the Colonel not succeed. which should
sincerely regret, am requested by several gentle
men from New Orleans, to name to you Captain

SPANISH FLEET.-A gentleman who arriv.
ed here yesterday in the schooner Sarah and Priste
lila, from Mayagnez, Porto Rico, informs the Amer
lean that short time previous to his sailing fleet
from Spain had arrived at St. Johns. 1t consisted
of three frigates and several smaller vessels, having
on board number oftroops. The report current
at St. Johns was, that the fleet was to proceed to
the Canaries, to receive on board the noted Gene
raj Morales as commander of the expedition, and
that descent was then to be made upon some point
on the Main. Our informant left Porto Rico on the
first Of the present month.
From the Baltimore .4n.eriean, Dee. IA.

English papers have been received at New York
as late as the 18th of November.


The Turkish fleet is tlestroyed-4 sail of the line;
Is frigates-l5 corvettes-9 brigs and numerous
The Turkish Admiral had $50 men kill
ed-and the loss of others was in proportion. The
loss of the Allies was great-English Al officers and
Q 8 men killed.-French above 100.


Particulars will be given in our next.


London, Nov 49,
Dispatches were yesterday received at the Ad-
mralty announcing brilliant victory obtained on
the Goth Oct. in the port of Nayarino by the En-
glish, French and Russian squadrons over the COM
bined Turkish and Egyptian fleets.


The battle was fought at anchor, and was neces-
sary bloody and destructive. The numerical SUI
periorty of the force was immense, but the result
has been, we are proud 10 say, the destruction OF
the whole Turkish force.


The following is Synopsis of the forces.

l
| Our readers will have noticed. in our account o!
the Proceedings of the House of Representatives,
yesterday, proposal of Mr.. F. p. Barbour, OF VIr-
gna, for the sale of the seven millions OF Stock OF
the Bank ofthe United States, owned by the Gov
ernment. re high responsibility Of the quarter
from which this proposal came, might have given
AN alarming consequence to the commercial colnmu-
nty had it not been met by the decided opposition
OF Messrs. McDufie and Gorham. The principal
Recommendation Of the measure prop sed by MIR. Il. |
appeared to be, the gam which would accrue to the
Treasury, by the advance of tWenty three per cent.
at which the Stock is now selling and which, on
Seven Millions of Dollars, would certainly amount
to very handsome sum. The fallacy, however, OF
supposng that Seven Millions Of Bank Stock, (one-


fifth of the whole amount Of the capital of the Bank
of the United States,) could be thrown into market,
without seriously affecting the price, was satisfactory
ly pointed out by the gentleman who spoke against
the proposition of Mr.. Barbour. The necessary et-
feet of such glut of the Stock market would, of
course, be enhanced by the jealously that would
arise in the money world, both at home and abroad
4 from seeing the Government, Gn whose hands rest
the power ofextendng the charter, and an impor-
tant control of the affairs of the Bank. dsembarrass
itself at once of the stock. The example OF the
Government would be followed by other Stockhold-
ers All, especially, who have purchased stock at
a high advance, would rush into the market to ad-
tcipate the Interpretation This deprecia-





creased, the panic would spread till tended at best


in fall of stock below par; result which would


nallby be productive of the most disastrous trans
fers, and forced sales, and general arrangement
: The worthy mover of the resolution does not ap
pear to have been wholly accurate in the supposltlon
that at the wndiugup Of the affairs Of the Bank, its
stock would be worth only par. In an institution
like this, surplus is of course reserved, in the final
! disposal and division Of which handsome dividend
: may be safely calculated upon.


The nature and operation of the various parts OF
the financial system OF the country are so delicate
and complicated that is exceedingly desirable that


they should not beunnecessariy dis urbed, even BY
: the proposal of changes The desirable effect OF
i producing an economy of the public money in the
IS payment Of the national debt, might be much more
advanageously obtained, by authorizing exchange
of stock, in the proposedby the Secretary o
n the Treasury at the last Congress, adopted by the
House of Representatives, and unfortunately lost
&c in the Senate. The sum lost to the Treasury, b,
t. the failure of that bill to become law exceeds the
lie amount paid for the salaries of all the Executive
ri and Judicial officers OF the Government, and O
lie all the Foreign Ministers.

that the people are determined to sustain the pres

Mr.. RANDOLPH has sustained the views we yester-
day threw out as to his incompetency to act as
Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means.
by sending to the Speaker his resignation of the Of
flee. If this step was not the result of reflection


if the objections we urged against his appointment
did not urge him to the measure we are left to
make the only inference which is left at our option
that he was originally appointed by the Speaker,
with the understanding that he should resign so as
to leave the chair vacant for Mir. McDuFFIE. We
can scarcely believe that the Speaker calculated on
a cordial co operation in the Committee between Mr.


RANDOLPH and Mr.. McDUFFIE, since he must have
recolected the contemptuous manner in which the
former expressed himself of the latter, and the in
dignant retort of Mr. McDufFe, some few years
since, in the course of a debate in the House OF
Representatives. 1t is probable that Mr. Randolph
has neither forgotten nor forgiven that retort. 1t
he has not, he could not serve on the Committee
with Mr.. McDuffie ; and if the Speaker knew this.
he must have made the appointment with full
knowledge that 1t would be resigned whether the
step now taken by Mr. Randolph is in fulflment Of
an original understanding or is the effect Of some
sudden insight into his own incompetency, we will


not decide In either case, the effect is the same
MIR. McDufie is the chairman ofthe Committee.

Robeson, Captain Saui, and Captain Richardson,
all q! whom are well recommended as 70 good char
acter and fitness for that Office"


There is certainly an awful squirting in this to-
wards military government, should it ever be the
misfortune of this country to have General Jackson
elected President. s.Shoud the Colonel not sue
ceed," says the General, i" am requested by sew
eral gentlemen from New Orleans to name to you

ar'son." We doubt not that these Captains were
very clever and deserving gentlemen, but then it sa-
yours too much of the military spirit for our taste
We must confess do not like to see civil offices
filled by mere soldiers. ID.

minstraton, if in minority now, however. is in a
very respectable one, which it is possible may swell
into majority before the day of trial comes.

ion have no doubt, in common with myself. read
with feelings of indignation the vile and slanderous
attack upon Kensey Johns, Junr. Esq. in the Della
ware Gazette. That such an attack was unexpect-
GU cannot assert-but that it was wholly unmerit-
ed and uncallel for, none but the miserable and pur-
chased wretch who made it will deny If ever
there was an individual whose amable and unas
snming good qualities could have disarmed political
fancour, that person was Mr.. Johns--but it seems
as II party strife spare nothing. Virtue, char
acler, religion itself is not exempt from its assaults,

and in the reclessnass Of lis pursuit even the COM
mon decencies and charities OF life are overlooked.
! Mr.. Johns has been wantonly and vulgarly as
salled because, iUIsooth, the present Speaker III
the House of Representatives, has not thought
proper 10 place him any of the standing commit
tees And to Justify what Harker considers in
territorial slight to the State he endeavours to shew,
or rather the pful blockhead asserts. that Mr..
Johns is without sufficient talent and requirements
for such situation This, affirm, is positively
false, and will be iumphantly proved whenever
his abilities put to the test. Mr.. Johns is not a
sudden made man. thrown out by the late political
excitement, which seems to have unhinged every
thing in the State. He has been for eight or ten
years at the Bar of this county, and earned by his
assiduous attention to his profession and amlabe de-
pertinent, not merely the goodwill, but the res
pect OF nearly all his associates Ills friends and
those who brought him forward on IA late Occa-
sion, saw in him degree of intelligence, united
with Il manly rectitude of purpose, which they
thought fully qualified him for his present situa-
ton. They knew that his judgment was sound.
and that his mind was sufficiently stored with
the important principles of law and legislation, to
render him safe depository of the trust they conf
ded to him. And they know and feel that the
cause of the omission alluded to- grows out of ve-
ry different from the assigned in the Ga
zette. They cannot permit themselves to doubt,
nor will any dsinterested and candid man (atter ex
aminng the complexion of the Committees that
have been appointed) that the why Mr..
Johns was passed over by the Speaker, was simply
because he known to be friendly to the present
Administration. What this state of things augurs
for the prosperity othe Country, is topic we will
not discuss.


Fortunately, the polluted source from which this
attack emenates, deplives it of the power to do mis-
chief-and nothing but the possibility of its receiv
ing credence abroad, where his character is unknown,
has induced me to notice it. should add, that the
writer of the present remarks, is not personal
friend of Mr.. Johns and that he has been inAuenc-
ed in what he has said solely from desire to do
justice. confess too, that am unwilling, as a
Deawarlan, to stand silently and see the reputation
Of man whom majority of my State has thought
worthy to represent her in Congress, assailed and
talsitied by any ignorant and degraded puppy who
may chance to edit paper And, additionally,
object that such creature as Harker, the willing
and humble tool of all or any who will consent to
employ him. should without contradiction, assume
to himself the province OF a public sentinel" We
Sir, who reside in this part of the country, knoU
him to be neither sentinel nor the organ of an,
party in the State. The most respectable of the


old Federalists, of whom he has been the worst en-


emy, and whose party he has so long labored t.


destroy, gave him up, one after another, some TIM
age. ne oe'noCFauC party always heio nun y


contempt. The present genuine &C bona .fde" Jack


sonitcs are afraid of his principles; for they Can


not forget that he has denounced their CHIEF " a


the most Objectionable of all the candidates for tn


presidency" And the eleventh hour Jackson mer
. who have the honor, or the disgrace to enrol hil
in their ranks not in very good circulation then
sclves, and at all events cannot be dgned with th
:: name ofa party. Let him. however, belong to wha


ever political sect he may, he has lost what litt
standing he had in the estimation of the better pa
0 of society, who in him the robber of priva
t reputation, and the ready sponsor of every politics
s. heresy. VlNDEA'

full articles.article:
Mr.. Diclerson, Senator of the United States
from New Jersey, has declared MS intention of re-
signing his seat at the close of the present session.
The people whom that Honorable gentleman con-
tinues to msrepresent will doubtless be much pleas
ed when they learn his determination.

full articles.article:
New ORLEANS, Nov. 22,-More Duels-A duel
took place on Sunday morning last, between Mr.
Dangerfield and Mi. Buckner, of Natchez. On
the third fire, the former mortally wounded, and
expired in three hours after.


DR. Newell and General Coffee fought duel at
jackson, Mississippi, few days since; the former
was wounded, but not mOrtally.

character ofthe Legislature appears very mantestly

Governor Trmblc's message sustans the power
of Congress to protect domestic industry, in very
lucid and powerful manner, and urges the exped-
ency of it but it seems unnecessary to lay his
views before our readers, at this time, since simi-
lar statements have been SO lately presenedto them
Of the Administration of the General Government,
he thus speaks.
Nor have we less cause to feel grateful when con-
templatiny the favorable and prosperous condition
of our common country. Under the guidance OF an
enlightened and liberal Administration, the great in
teress of the nation have continued to prosper, her
resources have been increased, the public debt re-
duced, and by mild, but firm execution Of the laws,
the rights ofhe citizens have been protected peace
and tranquility maintained, (both in our foreign u
domestic relations,) without resort to force and
under the peaceful influence OF our free institutions
we may repose in the perfect enjoyments OF civil
and religious liberty freedom ofthought ofspeech
and there are ''none to hurt or make US AFRAID


Mr.. Randolph has declined serving as Chairman
Of the Committee of Ways and Means-urging his
inability to discharge the duties in consequence of the
avery feeble state of his heath''-His voice is said
to be broken-&c. &C. Alexander Smyth. OF pro-
clamaton memory, and late an expounder OF the
apocaypse, was added to the Committee after the
House excused Mr.. Randolph. Mr.. M'Dutiie be-
comes the Chairman.


The Miners Journal-published in Schuylkill
county, Penn. states that Gov. Shulze cannot be
spared from that State for the Vice Presidency
and observes If his name vice President,
were connected with that of Mr. Adams, on the
Presidential ticket there is no doubt that ticket
would succeed in Pennsylvania by large nayority
The cause of the administration, however, requires
no such extraneous aid. Judging from the present
aspect of things, we are firmly Of the opinion, that
MIR. Adams will ultimately receive thevote Of Penn
sylvania."

ordinary expenses will be paid-and ten millions 9
public debt, and leaving between two and three mil


lions in the Treasury at the end of thr year.

We were very forcibly struck with the following

Master General in favor of Col. Croghan:


'.Should the Colonel not succeed. which should

full articles.headline: From the Baltimore .4n.eriean, Dee. IA.
full articles.article:
SPANISH FLEET.-A gentleman who arriv.
ed here yesterday in the schooner Sarah and Priste
lila, from Mayagnez, Porto Rico, informs the Amer
lean that short time previous to his sailing fleet
from Spain had arrived at St. Johns. 1t consisted
of three frigates and several smaller vessels, having
on board number oftroops. The report current
at St. Johns was, that the fleet was to proceed to
the Canaries, to receive on board the noted Gene
raj Morales as commander of the expedition, and
that descent was then to be made upon some point
on the Main. Our informant left Porto Rico on the
first Of the present month.

English papers have been received at New York
as late as the 18th of November.


The Turkish fleet is tlestroyed-4 sail of the line;
Is frigates-l5 corvettes-9 brigs and numerous
The Turkish Admiral had $50 men kill
ed-and the loss of others was in proportion. The
loss of the Allies was great-English Al officers and
Q 8 men killed.-French above 100.


Particulars will be given in our next.


London, Nov 49,
Dispatches were yesterday received at the Ad-
mralty announcing brilliant victory obtained on
the Goth Oct. in the port of Nayarino by the En-
glish, French and Russian squadrons over the COM
bined Turkish and Egyptian fleets.


The battle was fought at anchor, and was neces-
sary bloody and destructive. The numerical SUI
periorty of the force was immense, but the result
has been, we are proud 10 say, the destruction OF
the whole Turkish force.


The following is Synopsis of the forces.
inn Eriuts COrvpttps Sins. &c. Tot al.

full articles.headline: From the National MteMgcncer.
full articles.article:
l
| Our readers will have noticed. in our account o!
the Proceedings of the House of Representatives,
yesterday, proposal of Mr.. F. p. Barbour, OF VIr-
gna, for the sale of the seven millions OF Stock OF
the Bank ofthe United States, owned by the Gov
ernment. re high responsibility Of the quarter
from which this proposal came, might have given
AN alarming consequence to the commercial colnmu-
nty had it not been met by the decided opposition
OF Messrs. McDufie and Gorham. The principal
Recommendation Of the measure prop sed by MIR. Il. |
appeared to be, the gam which would accrue to the
Treasury, by the advance of tWenty three per cent.
at which the Stock is now selling and which, on
Seven Millions of Dollars, would certainly amount
to very handsome sum. The fallacy, however, OF
supposng that Seven Millions Of Bank Stock, (one-


fifth of the whole amount Of the capital of the Bank
of the United States,) could be thrown into market,
without seriously affecting the price, was satisfactory
ly pointed out by the gentleman who spoke against
the proposition of Mr.. Barbour. The necessary et-
feet of such glut of the Stock market would, of
course, be enhanced by the jealously that would
arise in the money world, both at home and abroad
4 from seeing the Government, Gn whose hands rest
the power ofextendng the charter, and an impor-
tant control of the affairs of the Bank. dsembarrass
itself at once of the stock. The example OF the
Government would be followed by other Stockhold-
ers All, especially, who have purchased stock at
a high advance, would rush into the market to ad-
tcipate the Interpretation This deprecia-





creased, the panic would spread till tended at best


in fall of stock below par; result which would


nallby be productive of the most disastrous trans
fers, and forced sales, and general arrangement
: The worthy mover of the resolution does not ap
pear to have been wholly accurate in the supposltlon
that at the wndiugup Of the affairs Of the Bank, its
stock would be worth only par. In an institution
like this, surplus is of course reserved, in the final
! disposal and division Of which handsome dividend
: may be safely calculated upon.


The nature and operation of the various parts OF
the financial system OF the country are so delicate
and complicated that is exceedingly desirable that


they should not beunnecessariy dis urbed, even BY
: the proposal of changes The desirable effect OF
i producing an economy of the public money in the
IS payment Of the national debt, might be much more
advanageously obtained, by authorizing exchange
of stock, in the proposedby the Secretary o
n the Treasury at the last Congress, adopted by the
House of Representatives, and unfortunately lost
&c in the Senate. The sum lost to the Treasury, b,
t. the failure of that bill to become law exceeds the
lie amount paid for the salaries of all the Executive
ri and Judicial officers OF the Government, and O
lie all the Foreign Ministers.

tans an order of his Majesty in council, permitting
vessels of the United States to enter ports of the
Bahama Islands, in ballast, for the purpose Of ex-
porting thence fruit and salt.

full articles.article:
We have seen several letters from Washington,
which speak in the most pleasing terms of the pros
poets of Mr.. Adams reelection. The information
from all parts of the country evnce most clearly,
that the people are determined to sustain the pres
ent vrtuous and enlightened administration and
by their votes to frown down the unrighteous spirit
of persecution, with which they have been pursued
Line. Frigts. Corvettes. Sips. sc. Tot al.
